Grant Description: This grant supports the launch of The Massachusetts Personalized Learning Network (PLN), which seeks to create a critical mass of equity-minded schools that exemplify personalized, competency-based, and engaged learning approaches. Focused on eastern MA urban communities, with the school districts of Revere, Framingham, Boston, and Somerville considered for the first two annual PLN cohorts, PLN schools will offer an educational experience that is personalized, project-based, and attuned to the unique academic and social-emotional needs of students. Funding will support key staff and professional development activities through the initial phases of the first and second cohorts of schools. If particular targets are met, CCE may be invited to apply for continued funding for this work.

Grant Description: CCE will assist selected secondary schools and districts to implement high quality performance assessment systems with fidelity by building the capacity of Teacher Leaders, building administrators, and school officials across the state to lead this work in their respective school(s) and to serve as resources for neighboring school districts. Six high schools will become PBGR Demonstration Schools; they will convene showcases intended to help drive the implementation of PBGR across the state. Eleven additional schools will receive professional development in scaling their efforts across grade levels to increase cognitive rigor, teacher ownership and student agency in meeting the demands of the states PBGR. CCE will also convene a series of workshops open to school teams across the state.

Grant Description: Funding to support the Health Access Campaign which advocates for health care coverage for all immigrants. MIRA supports bills to lift caps for the Childrenâ€™s Medical Security Plan, reduce out-of-pocket costs, and reinsert affordability protections for the lowest-income residents ineligible for Masshealth. MIRA will also convene a Task Force on Immigrant Healthcare Professionals to examine barriers to relicensing faced by thousands of foreign-trained health care professionals.

Grant Recipient Name: Massachusetts League of Community Health Centers
Grant Population Served: Low-income people
Grant Support Strategy: Policy, advocacy and systems reform; Program support
Grant Description: Funding to address the changes in the policy and health care environment with vulnerable populations, community health centers, and their communities. A main goal is to analyze health care reform policies, monitor proposals for change, and educate community health centers and partner organizations. The League will also assemble health centers, community members, providers, and advocates in an action-based coalition for maintaining and expanding coverage.

Grant Funder Name: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: People with disabilities
Grant Support Strategy: Systems reform; Litigation; Equal access; Program support
Grant Description: Funding to ensure universal access to quality health care in Massachusetts, particularly for those at-risk due to factors such as race, gender, disability, age, or geographic location. HLA supports four initiatives: the Health Care Reform Initiative, the Childrenâ€™s Mental Health Access Project, the Medical Debt Initiative, and the Pro Bono Legal Network Program. HLA will provide individual representation for Massachusetts residents under 300% FPL who have been denied access to health care or have received unaffordable medical bills, public policy advocacy and, where necessary, class-action litigation.

Grant Population Served: Families
Grant Description: Funding to support Urban Edge and The Family Van to partner with Winn Companies toanalyze the impact that housing support services have on the health of families most impacted by the social determinants of health, using an Evaluation Framework for Community Health Programs. Urban Edge provides housing supportive services including public benefit enrollment, family budgeting, leadership development, connections to community, and tax preparation services. The Family Van carries out curbside testing, health coaching, and care referrals to individuals in underserved communities, travelling directly to areas in which the need is greatest, andproviding a range of preventive services and an alternative to costly emergency department visits.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Recipient Name: Family Health Center Of Worcester Inc
Grant Population Served: People with diseases and illnesses
Grant Description: Please provide a brief description of the proposed projecamily Health Center of Worcester is working to complete a $9.13 Million capital campaign to improve access to care for low income residents, and to upgrade our facilities. The project will fund the physical expansion and renovation of our main administrative, clinical, and teaching site at 26 Queen Street, Worcester. This expansion and renovation will allow FHCW to meet the significant increase in demand for primary care, vision care, pharmacy, and dental services for approximately 7,000 new patients. Construction completed to-date to add 18,000 S.F. On th ground floor of the building has provided a fourth primary care team with 20 exam rooms which opened in 12/2013 to provide an estimated 4,835 new patients with access to a primary care medical home; 4 new dental operatories on the third floor, bringing the total to 14, to address the overwhelming demand for urgent/emergency dental treatment and preventive care; a new vision/optical service in partnership with the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy & Health Sciences (MCPHS) which opened in 5/2014 to provide eye care for low income,to accommodate 22% increase in our patient population. Family Health Center of Worcester currently provides services for over 33,000 area residents. Phase 2 of the project includes renovations to refresh paint and flooring in 56,000 square feet of existing health center clinical and teaching space to update and repair the facility; construct new nurses stations on 3 existing clinical teams to allow more efficient workflow and consistent work spaces; renovate two storage spaces to convert to office space for improved patient confidentiality in HIV counseling and testing, and health education; and replace aged equipment in disrepair throughout the health center to assure sustainability of operations well into the future.

Grant Description: Springfield No One Leaves (SNOL) seeks support for our Springfield Tenants Organizing Project to organize renters to defend against displacement and expand renterâ€™s rights in the city of Springfield. SNOL formed in 2010 in the wake of the foreclosure crisis. Our initial work was to combat the predatory practices of Wall Street banks that displaced thousands of low and moderate-income families, disproportionately families of color. The STOP will broaden our work to organize thousands of low-income renters to win victories that can serve as a model for the housing justice movement nationally.

Grant Description: To support the organization and installation of an exhibit for NCF'S 25TH Anniversary celebration. Grant Description: Pioneer Valley Workers Center (PVWC) is requesting general support for our food system organizing work. Grant Population Served: Victims and oppressed people
Grant Description: We respectfully request funds for general operating support for the Healthcare for Homeless Families Program (HFHF). HFHF is designed to address the underlying causes of a family's homeless episode, and treat the physical and/or mental health conditions that may contribute to job loss, housing loss, the exhaustion of a families' support system and subsequent shelter placement. For 25 years, the HFHF has been the only program in Worcester to provide comprehensive access to health care services for homeless family members of all ages, with coordinated and integrated case management, access to behavioral health care, and trauma-informed primary care. Unlike housing-centered homeless programs, the HFHF assists the most vulnerable women and children in our community by providing wrap-around services at Family Health Center of Worcester (FHCW) structured with an awareness of the devastatingly high rate of violence encountered within homeless families. This past year we saw a 51% increase in the demand for HFHF services and, based upon the continuing high rates of shelter enrollment, we expect the need to continue. The HFHF provides trauma-informed healthcare, coupled with intensive case management to homeless family members so that they emerge from their time in shelter with the tools to navigate the healthcare system for themselves and their families. The goal of the program is to support families to resolve underlying health and trauma issues, and establish goals to move freely along the pathway toward stability and self-sufficiency. The HFHF employs two case managers (family advocates), the HFHF director who provides services as a social worker and supervises the advocates, the HFHF medical director (M.D.), And a consulting psychologist. We request funding to support non-reimbursable case management services needed to provide wrap around, trauma-informed care for the growing number of homeless families.

Grant Description: Youth Justice and Power Union (YJPU) is a grassroots youth of color-led organizing group in Boston leading a campaign to increase youth jobs funding and youth employment. We request funding for our fourth year of long-standing campaign work to increase employment for young people of color in Boston, particularly those who are systematically excluded from employment -- LGBTQ youth people of color, court involved youth, etc. Our work engages a base of young people of color most affected in Boston to lead campaign work to change city policies that hurt them and their communities.

Grant Description: By 2018, eight million jobs in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) will be available in the United States. Unfortunately, the vast majority of our students will be unprepared to fill them. The root of the problem is the quality of the math and science education in our schools, which disproportionately affects children of color and those from low-income communities and threatens to leave entire groups of students without the skills needed for 21ST century jobs: according to the 2011 National Assessment of Educational Progress, only 15% of low-income 4TH graders are proficient in science and, by the time they graduate high school, many will not prepared to major in STEM fields in college. Massachusetts is no exception: in 2014, only 1 in 3 low-income students in Massachusetts were proficient or advanced in Mathematics and Science. Meanwhile, more than twice as many non-low income students scored proficient or advanced in both subjects.

Grant Population Served: Ethnic and racial groups; Low-income people; People with disabilities; People with HIV/AIDS
Grant Description: Through our Nutrition Program for Individuals and Families Living with Critical Illnesses in Worcester, we will deliver 24,000 medically-tailored meals to the doorsteps of 90 low-income individuals and families affected by a critical illness and provide these clients with 135 hours of nutrition education and counseling. Each week Community Servings will deliver 5 days worth of customized, nutritionally-packed lunches, dinners, and snacks to the door-steps of our critically ill clients, their dependents and caregivers who live in Worcester. Each client's meals are tailored by our Registered Dietitian, in consultation with clients and their healthcare provider, to offer specialized nutrition care -- the correct balance of nutrients and calories to help the client to combat a specific disease, gain or maintain weight and muscle mass, and manage the effects of drugs and other powerful medical treatments.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: Students
Grant Description: Youthconnect Summer 2015 will provide opportunities in the evening for middle school youth during the summer, age 11 - 15. The program will operate tentatively 6/ 29 - 8/14. Each weeknight, one recreational facility per team will be open, 5:30 - 9:30PM for a host of activities. Activities typically include: aerobics, arts and crafts, basketball, cooking, games, movies, swimming, volleyball, etc. More structured activities will be determined after the first few weeks of operation. For Youthnet to maximize its effect and service the cities youth who are most at risk, we recognize the need for full time staff to be out in the community during the afternoon hours developing relationships and building trust with our youth. Youthconnect mission is to provide high quality neighborhood-based recreational, educational and cultural activities to isolated and underserved Worcester youth for middle school age youth. Youthconnect emerged from the very successful Youthnet collaboration providing culturally competent developmental summer programs to Worcester's middle school youth for 20 years. Partners include: Boys & Girls Club of Worcester, Friendly House, Girls Inc. Of Worcester, YMCA of Central MA, Y.O.U. Inc., YWCA of Central MA, and Worcester Youth Center. These partners share a commitment to provide year round youth development opportunities to youth who reside in Worcesterâ€™s highest environments. Youthconnect has accomplished what no single agency could it has managed to provide healthy alternatives to all of Worcester's subsidized housing complexes and low income neighborhoods it has also provided transportation to all its participants thus reaching the more isolated and undeserved of Worcester's youth. And all of this has been offered at no cost to the participants or their families While offering such a free program has required aggressive fundraising, we realize the feasibility of generating revenues by charging a fee would net minimal funds.

Grant Recipient Name: The Family Van, a Program of the President and Fellows of Harvard College
Grant Population Served: Families
Grant Description: Mobile clinics bring high quality care into communities to improve the detection and management of chronic diseases for our most vulnerable populations. Given the Family Van's long history of success in increasing access to healthcare in Boston's most underserved communities, we now see an opportunity to expand our model and broaden our scope of impact while promoting health equity in Massachusetts. The Family Van proposes expanding its services to a new community, which will allow us to reach hundreds of new clients each year by bringing much needed preventive health care services and health counseling to the underserved. Funding from the Boston Scientific Foundation would allow us to work with community residents, partner organizations, and local health officials to identify and launch a new site in Massachusetts in either Quincy or Saugus.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: Children; Families
Grant Description: The African Community Education Program (ACE) is requesting funding from the Fred Harris Daniels Foundation to support our Family Education Program and wraparound outreach services for families. Our Family Education Program includes adult English for Speakers of Other Languages (ESOL), U.S. Citizenship classes, an early literacy playgroup for ESOL studentsâ€™ children ages 0-9, and parent-child literacy activities. We propose that Daniels funding would support hours for our Family Education Coordinator to coordinate adult classes, the early literacy playgroup and parent-child literacy activities; hours for family programming support staff; and for 4 ACE Outreach Workers to provide wraparound support to these families. We will hold family education programming on Saturday mornings from 9:30 A.M. To 1:30 P.M., Running from October 2015 through June 2016. To overcome potential barriers to participation, we provide free on-site childcare through our early literacy playgroup, a free breakfast and lunch, and free bus passes.
